courseDescription: Preclinical experience in the on-campus supervised clinic.  Clinical and laboratory application of introductory skills essential to rendering oral health services to patients with emphasis on basic dental hygiene instrumentation and ergonomics. Offered each fall.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in a clinical setting

courseDescription: A study of the anatomical, histological, embryological and morphological features and development of the head, neck and dentition. Emphasis is on nomenclature, nerve and vascular innervation, muscles of mastication, orofacial embryology and histological features of the oral cavity for practice and forensic identification.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of anatomical structures in the head, neck, and dentition
Understanding of histological features of the oral cavity
Familiarity with nerve and vascular innervation in the oral region
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of anatomical and histological information
Collaboration with peers on anatomical studies
Presentation of findings related to orofacial embryology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of morphological features for forensic purposes
Evaluation of embryological development in the orofacial region
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on histological features
Taking initiative in identifying and studying relevant aspects of oral anatomy

courseDescription: An introduction to biomaterials with emphasis on those materials and techniques common in dental hygiene practice and used and maintained by the dental hygienist.  (offered fall)
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of dental materials used in practice
Techniques for working with dental materials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with dental team regarding materials
Collaboration with dentists and other dental professionals on material selection
Patient education on dental materials and maintenance
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying appropriate materials for specific dental procedures
Analyzing the durability and effectiveness of different dental materials
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on best practices for material use in dental hygiene practice
Providing guidance and training to other dental hygienists on material techniques

courseDescription: Study of the nature and production of x rays and basic principles and procedures in oral radiology.  Emphasis is on radiation physics, radiation biology, radiation protection and safety, basic intraoral radiographic techniques and imaging procedures. (offered fall)

Continuation of study of the theoretical foundation of preventive and therapeutic oral health services used in the dental hygiene process.  Emphasis is on preparation for ethical, evidence-based client care. (offered spring).
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of oral health data
Problem identification in oral health services

courseDescription: Clinical experience in the on-campus supervised clinic.  Continued development of clinical proficiency and ethical, evidence-based decision making in rendering comprehensive preventive oral health services using the dental hygiene process.  Emphasis is on clinical application and development of competence in maintenance, management and evaluation of the periodontal patient; care planning, disease control strategies; and scaling and oral debridement on periodontally involved patients (offered spring).
Technical and Digital Skills: Clinical proficiency in preventive oral health services
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients and colleagues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of periodontal patient care plans
Management and assessment of periodontally involved patients
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Competence development in maintenance of patient records
Leadership in clinical application and development

courseDescription: A study of pharmacologic agents used in oral healthcare and of medications that the patient may be taking, their clinical effects, adverse effects, and dental implications, and the prevention and management of medical emergencies.  Emphasis is on agents commonly used by patients which may require the alteration of treatment procedures, therapeutic agents used adjunctively in dental hygiene therapy and agents used in medical emergency procedures. (offered spring)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding pharmacologic agents in oral healthcare
Knowledge of medications and their effects
Management of medical emergencies in a dental setting
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients regarding medication use
Working collaboratively with dental team during emergencies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in adjusting treatment procedures based on patient medications
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading medical emergency response in a dental office

courseDescription: Principles of the disease process and general pathology including cell injury, infection, inflammation, neoplasia and circulatory disturbances are followed by the study of pathology of the teeth, supporting and associated oral structures.  Emphasis is on the clinical and radiological appearance of local and systemic disease processes affecting the oral and facial structures. (offered spring)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding disease processes in oral and facial structures
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients and colleagues
Team collaboration in diagnosis and treatment planning
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Diagnosing oral diseases based on clinical and radiological findings
Identifying systemic disease manifestations in oral tissues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading interdisciplinary teams in oral pathology cases
Managing patient treatment plans and follow-ups

courseDescription: Continued development of the principles and techniques obtained in Oral Radiology I with emphasis on supplemental intraoral techniques especially for client management; extraoral techniques; radiographic interpretation of film-based and digitally acquired images; and use of dental photography in patient care. (offered spring)
Technical and Digital Skills: Radiographic interpretation of digitally acquired images
Utilization of dental photography in patient care
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of oral health issues from radiographs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Efficient workflow management in radiology procedures

courseDescription: Emphasis is on principles of periodontics, evaluation of periodontal disease, and theoretical and clinical preparation for delivery of dental hygiene interventions. (offered spring)
Technical and Digital Skills: Clinical preparation for dental hygiene interventions

courseTitle: Dental Hygiene Theory and Services III
courseDescription: Clinical experience in the on-campus supervised clinic. Continued development of clinical competency and ethical, evidence-based decision making in rendering comprehensive preventive  and therapeutic oral health services and technologies using the dental hygiene process of care. (offered summer)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Professional interaction in a clinical setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision making based on evidence and data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in a clinical setting

courseDescription: Clinical experience in the on-campus supervised clinic.  Principles and techniques for local anesthesia injections and nitrous oxide-oxygen analgesia administration, neurophysiologic considerations, prevention of anesthesia-associated emergencies and application of techniques in laboratory.  Five hours of instruction will be web-based. (Offered summer)
Selected topics in dental hygiene vary by semester. (offered fall, spring, summer)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Treatment planning based on patient needs

courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic selected under direction of a faculty member.  (offered fall, spring, summer)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of dental hygiene literature
Identifying research gaps in dental hygiene field

courseDescription: Study of the psychosocial, physical and oral characteristics of patients with special needs.  Emphasis is on the care and clinical management of the following patients:  cognitively, developmentally and physically challenged, aged, pregnant, epileptic, diabetic, cancer, AIDS, chemically dependent and the blind and deaf. (offered fall)
Technical and Digital Skills: Clinical management of patients with special needs
Understanding oral characteristics of patients with special needs
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with cognitively, developmentally, and physically challenged patients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying appropriate care methods for patients with special needs
Adapting treatment plans based on patient characteristics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating care for patients with multiple special needs
Leading a team in providing comprehensive care

courseDescription: Clinical experience in the on-campus supervised clinic.  Continued development of clinical proficiency and ethical, evidence-based decision making in providing comprehensive preventive and therapeutic oral health services.  Emphasis is on intra/interprofessional clinical application and development of competencies for the treatment of diverse, special needs and periodontally involved patients using the dental hygiene process of care.  (offered fall)
Technical and Digital Skills: Clinical proficiency in preventive and therapeutic oral health services
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ethical decision making in oral health services
Effective communication with diverse patients and special needs individuals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of patient treatment plans
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Development of competencies for treating periodontally involved patients

courseDescription: Course is designed for the licensed dental hygienist who seeks to maintain an awareness of changing trends, perspectives, evidence-based interventions and technologies in dental hygiene, health, and society that influence the dental hygiene process of care. This is a writing intensive course. (Offered summer)
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of evidence-based interventions in dental hygiene
Awareness of changing trends in technology in dental hygiene
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex dental hygiene concepts to patients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of evidence-based practices in dental hygiene
Analytical skills for assessing new technologies in dental hygiene
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in implementing new dental hygiene practices
Management of dental hygiene process of care

courseDescription: Introduction to the principles of dental public health, health literacy, oral epidemiology, evidenced-based prevention and control of oral disease on a population basis.  Emphasis is on program assessment, planning, implementation, and evaluation for the development of community-based dental programs.  This course prepares students for the role of oral health educator, client advocate and resource person in community settings.  (offered fall)

courseTitle: Educational Concepts for the Health Professional I
courseDescription: This course is designed to explore various educational concepts, principles and methods of teaching for adults. Students will learn to present educational information to a diverse client population, in a variety of settings, in an ethical and professional manner. Topics include, but are not limited to, objectives, planning, implementation and evaluation of instruction; instructional strategies; delivery models; presentation skills; and techniques for communicating health information.

courseTitle: Research Methods in the Health Sciences
courseDescription: Designed to develop skills in scientific methods, evidence based decision making and critical analysis of research findings. Emphasis on types of research, levels of evidence, problem selection and hypothesis writing, research planning and design, data collection and measuring techniques, analysis and interpretation of data, research proposal writing and computer application.  A written research proposal is required for graduate credit.(offered fall)

A study of current trends that influence the profession of dental hygiene including oral health care delivery, manpower, financing mechanisms, quality improvement, third party payers, professional associations,  regulatory agencies and legislation.  Emphasis is on ethical, political, and legal issues as they relate to the dental hygiene profession. offered spring)
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in using online collaboration platforms
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Conflict resolution skills in a professional setting
Ability to lead and participate in group discussions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing ethical dilemmas in a professional context
Analyzing regulatory requirements and implications for decision-making

courseDescription: Clinical experience in the on-campus supervised clinic.  Continued development of proficiency and ethical, evidence-based decision making in providing comprehensive preventive and therapeutic oral health services within the dental hygiene process of care.  Emphasis is on intra/interprofessional development of competencies for the treatment of periodontally involved, special needs and diverse patients. (offered spring)
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in providing preventive and therapeutic oral health services
Ethical decision-making in dental hygiene care process
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with special needs and diverse patients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of patient needs and treatment options

courseDescription: Interprofessional service-learning and internship experiences designed to prepare students to function as oral health practitioners, educators, client advocates and resource persons in community health settings. Emphasis is on providing evidenced-based educational, preventive, and therapeutic services for vulnerable and underserved populations including low-income, geriatric, pediatric, institutionalized, and cognitively, developmentally, and physically challenged individuals. Design and delivery of a poster session is required. (offered spring; varies days and times)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of oral health practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Advocating for policy change in healthcare
Leading oral health initiatives in diverse populations

courseDescription: This course examines the concept, global impact, and trends in telehealthcare technology on the client/patient, multidisciplinary practitioners, and various healthcare systems.  Emphasis is on effective evidence-based decision making to reduce errors in patient care, promote care in remote or underserved geographical areas, and the ability to retrieve and evaluate healthcare information that improves access to quality, cost effective health care. (Offered spring)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients and multidisciplinary practitioners
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational management in remote healthcare systems

courseDescription: International locations are determined by the School of Dental Hygiene in conjunction with the Office of Study Abroad.  Program participation requires approval from the School of Dental Hygiene and the Office of Study Abroad.  Provides an on-location international experience in oral care delivery, practice and regulation, and dental hygiene education.  Students will be required to give presentations, review the dental care delivery system, and explore how the cultural beliefs and practices affect oral health, dental care seeking behaviors, and the oral health status of the population.  Orientations will be conducted prior to travel.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of oral care delivery systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing cultural influences on oral health
Identifying barriers to dental care access
Developing solutions for improving oral health outcomes
Critical evaluation of cultural practices and beliefs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adapting to changing environments during travel

courseTitle: Ergonomics and Exercises for Static Posture Occupations
courseDescription: This active participation course is designed for persons who work in static posture professions (e.g., dental hygienists, laboratory and computer office personnel) and who seek to practice ergonomic body mechanics and exercise therapies to prevent musculoskeletal disorders and repetitive strain injuries. Topics include biomechanics, creating an ergonomically sound work space, alternative sitting and standing techniques during clinical care, types of disorders and injuries, risk management, comprehension and demonstration of full body exercises with emphasis on core strength training, and self-monitoring. (offered online summer session only)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating on ergonomic solutions with team members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying musculoskeletal disorders and repetitive strain injuries
Analyzing risks associated with static posture professions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading ergonomic training sessions for colleagues
Implementing ergonomic strategies in the workplace

courseDescription: Seminars on selected topics in dental hygiene. Topics vary by semester.  (offered fall, spring, summer)
Technical and Digital Skills: Electronic health records management in dental practice
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Patient education on dental hygiene practices
Effective communication with patients about treatment plans
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing treatment plans based on patient needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a dental hygiene team during patient care
Implementing new dental hygiene protocols in a practice

courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic selected under direction of a faculty member.  (Offered fall, spring, summer)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in evaluating dental hygiene literature

courseDescription: Supervised research on a specific problem in dental hygiene.  Regular meetings with faculty and a written/oral report are required.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying specific problems in dental hygiene

courseDescription: Course is designed for the licensed dental hygienist who seeks to maintain an awareness of changing trends, perspectives, evidence-based interventions and technologies in dental hygiene, health, and society that influence the dental hygiene process of care.  (Offered summer.)
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of evidence-based interventions in dental hygiene
Awareness of changing trends in dental hygiene practice
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients and colleagues
Working collaboratively in a healthcare team
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of evidence-based practices in dental hygiene
Analyzing the impact of societal trends on dental hygiene practice
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in dental hygiene practice
Leadership in patient education and advocacy
Organizing and leading dental hygiene interventions

courseTitle: Educational Concepts for the Health Professional I
courseDescription: This course is designed to explore various educational concepts, principles and methods of teaching for adults. Students will learn to present educational information to a diverse client population, in a variety of settings, in an ethical and professional manner. Topics include, but are not limited to, objectives, planning, implementation and evaluation of instruction; instructional strategies; delivery models; presentation skills; and techniques for communicating health information. (offered fall)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with diverse client population

courseTitle: Research Methods in the Health Sciences
courseDescription: Designed to develop skills in scientific methods, evidence based decision making, levels of evidence, and critical analysis of research findings. Emphasis on types of research, problem selection and hypothesis writing, research planning and design, data collection and measuring techniques, analysis and interpretation of data, research proposal writing and computer application.  A written research proposal is required for graduate credit. (offered fall)
Technical and Digital Skills: Research methods in the health sciences

courseDescription: A study of current trends that influence the profession of dental hygiene including oral health care delivery, manpower, financing mechanisms, quality improvement, third party payers, professional associations,  regulatory agencies and legislation.  Emphasis is on ethical, political, and legal issues as they relate to the dental hygiene profession. (offered spring)

This course will examine the concept, global impact, and trends in telehealthcare technology on the client/patient, multidisciplinary practitioners, and various healthcare systems.  Emphasis is on effective evidence-based decision making to reduce errors in patient care, promote care in remote or underserved geographical areas, and the ability to retrieve and evaluate healthcare information that improves access to quality, cost effective health care. (Offered spring)
Technical and Digital Skills: Data retrieval and evaluation in healthcare systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of evidence-based decision making in telehealthcare
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Error reduction in patient care through data analysis
Problem-solving for underserved geographical areas in healthcare
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational management for cost-effective healthcare access
Decision-making for improving quality of healthcare services

courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic selected under direction of a faculty member. (Offered fall, spring, summer)
Technical and Digital Skills: Literature review techniques in oral health studies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings to peers and faculty
Collaborating with other researchers in the field of dental hygiene
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of dental hygiene literature
Identifying gaps in current research in oral health
Developing research questions in dental hygiene
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively for independent study
Taking initiative in pursuing research in dental hygiene
Demonstrating leadership in conducting dental hygiene research

courseDescription: The application of principles and theories of education and management to dental hygiene clinical education.  Emphasis is on planning, implementing and evaluating clinical teaching, assessment of clinical competence, management of human and physical resources, and regulations affecting clinical education. This course is offered only during fall semester.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with students and staff
Conflict resolution in a clinical setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and implementation of clinical education programs

courseTitle: Modeling and Simulation Applications in Healthcare
courseDescription: This course examines the principles and innovative applications for modeling and simulation in healthcare practice, research, education, and administration with emphasis on emerging issues and trends in technology.  Topics include the selection and implementation of simulation technology in conceptual epidemiology public and environmental health, dental hygiene, dentistry, nursing, medicine, laboratory sciences, healthcare management and health information. (offered summer)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing simulation data for healthcare trends
Developing innovative simulation applications for healthcare
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading simulation projects in healthcare settings
Managing simulation technology implementation in healthcare organizations

courseDescription: This course will expose the inter-professional student to current and future challenges of aging in our society. Topics will include Healthy People 2020 objectives, health promotion and disease prevention for the aging, sociocultural issues, and theories on behavior and motivation. Common systemic and oral health conditions of the aging adult will be identified. Critical analysis of the current health environment will provide a format for discussion and identification of strategies for health promotion and disease control for the aging. Measures for promoting and maintaining oral health and overall health of the aging population will be explored, with attention to current research from the literature. This course is offered during summer semesters only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Health promotion strategies for the aging population
Identifying common systemic and oral health conditions in aging adults
Utilizing current research from literature for health promotion in the aging population
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Inter-professional collaboration in addressing aging challenges
Effective communication with aging individuals and their families
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of the current health environment related to aging
Identification of strategies for health promotion and disease control in the aging population
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing measures for promoting and maintaining oral health and overall health in aging adults
Leading discussions on sociocultural issues and theories related to aging

courseDescription: Faculty-led experiences offer unique opportunities for students to travel abroad, develop cross cultural competence, experience global health challenges, and engage in projects that advance oral health worldwide.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of global health challenges
Developing solutions for global health disparities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading projects to advance oral health worldwide
Managing cross-cultural teams in global health initiatives
Strategic planning for international dental hygiene projects

courseTitle: Educational Concepts for the Health Professional II
courseDescription: Explores instructional strategies and their application to contemporary health professional roles.  Emphasis is on individuals as health care specialists in business and industry; professional, private and public organizations; higher education; and the health care industry.  Topics include implementation and evaluation of instruction, roles and responsibilities of faculty within an accredited program affected by state and national standards, and ethical and career related issues and trends.  Students are provided with practical experience in traditional and distance education instructional methods. (offered spring)
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Roles and responsibilities within educational programs

courseDescription: Course brings together students from various health disciplines to learn each other's roles and collaborate as a team using technology to promote health and prevent disease.  Focus will be on optimizing health efforts and outcomes through an interprofessional approach that is guided by the research evidence and current technologies. Topics include Healthy People 2020 objectives, age, specific clinical guidelines for health promotion and illness prevention, theories on behavior and motivation, sociocultural issues, telehealth care, and various health problems.  Evidence-based measures used by the team for promoting and maintaining health throughout the lifespan are emphasized. (spring only)
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing telehealth technologies for healthcare delivery
Implementing evidence-based measures for health promotion
Understanding and applying Healthy People 2020 objectives
Using current technologies for promoting and maintaining health
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with team members from various health disciplines
Effective communication of health promotion strategies
Working as a team to optimize health outcomes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing research evidence for health promotion
Applying clinical guidelines for health promotion and disease prevention
Critical evaluation of behavior theories and motivation strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and coordinating team efforts for health optimization
Guiding the team based on current research evidence

courseDescription: Experience-based learning activities designed to develop a role of competence related to the individual’s area of specialization while working under the supervision of a faculty member or host supervisor within an educational, health care, research, or corporate health setting.  A clinical dental hygiene internship is prerequisite to DNTH 669.  Available for pass/fail grade only.  (offered fall, spring, summer as available)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Team collaboration in a professional setting
Effective communication with supervisors and colleagues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to new challenges and tasks
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in a work environment

courseDescription: This practicum course is for students to apply principles and theories of education and management to dental hygiene clinical education. Emphasis is on planning, implementing, and evaluating clinical teaching, assessment of clinical competence, management of human and physical resources, and regulations affecting clinical education. This course is only offered during fall semester.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Feedback delivery to students and staff
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and resolution of clinical education challenges
Data analysis for clinical performance evaluation

courseDescription: Advanced seminars on selected topics in dental hygiene.  Topics vary by semester.  (offered fall, spring, summer)
Independent reading and study on a topic selected under direction of a faculty member.  (offered fall, spring, summer)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers in the field of dental hygiene
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Designing research methodologies for dental studies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on dental hygiene topics

courseDescription: An original thesis research project executed with the major advisor and thesis committee supervising the student's research project.  A written research proposal must be submitted and approved prior to beginning the project.  Required for students in the thesis option. Available as pass/fail grade only. (offered fall, spring, summer).

Devoted to research, writing of the thesis, and scheduled conferences with the candidate's advisor and thesis committee.  Students must submit an acceptable written thesis demonstrating knowledge of problem selection, data classification, analysis and interpretation and defend it.  Available as pass/fail grade only.  (offered fall, spring, summer)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Scheduled conferences with advisor and thesis committee

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
